conclusion: Introduction to the problem and identification of known variables.
The ball is at rest, so the vector sum of all forces is zero.
Three forces acting on the ball: tension in the string, weight of the ball, and electric force.
Weight \(mg\) acts straight down, electric force \(qE\) is horizontal, tension \(T\) is along the string.
Tension \(T\) acts upwards and towards the left due to the electric field being horizontal.
Assume the charge is positive, so the electric force acts in the same direction as the field.
Vertical component of tension balances weight, horizontal component balances electric force.
Break down tension \(T\) into components: \(T \cos \theta\) and \(T \sin \theta\).
Substitute \(T\) into the second equation: \(\frac{mg}{\cos \theta} \cdot \sin \theta = qE\).
Consider the sign of the charge and direction of the electric field.
Conclude that the magnitude of \(E\) is the same regardless of charge sign.
